post.content:
In 1 Kings 11:4, did Solomon fall back into sin at the end of his life?

Solomon made two very important mistakes in his life.

The first was that he ignored God‚Äôs instruction not to amass horses for himself, in other words, not to build up his military forces, because that would show a lack of trust in Jehovah‚Äôs saving power, and the second, which had far worse consequences, was that he ignored God‚Äôs instruction not to take foreign wives. (Deuteronomy 17:16; 1 Kings 11:1‚Äì8)

He ignored that second instruction so completely and spectacularly that he ended up with what was doubtless the world‚Äôs finest ever poon collection, thousands of wives and concubines. And what happened? As he got older, his wives basically nagged him into apostasy, that is, into serving their false pagan gods.

This, but times 1000.

Needless to say, Jehovah was not impressed. (1 Kings 11:9‚Äì13)

Solomon is a good example for us that even the person faithful in least is faithful in much, and the person unfaithful in what is least will likely be unfaithful in much. (Luke 16:10)
post.author: sam

post.content:
Then came the worst phase, I got a new friend(he was never interested in going for med, he already decided to go for BSC once the NEET coaching gets over),who was very well spoken and very friendly. We became best of friends in no time.Then, we started to roam around the city in evening, going to restaurants, movies, bunking classes, etc. Eventually I totally got cut off from my studies. Full day enjoyment and gossips, that's how we wasted the other 7‚Äì8 months and then we went back home once the coaching got over.

It's been 6‚Äì7 years, still those memories hurts me a lot, as I end up not getting into any Medical college (no regrets as I haven't studied well) and wasting my parent‚Äôs hard earned money and shattering their dream of seeing me as a Doctor.

P.S 1 : Today I'm in a well paid job working as a System Engineer in a reputed IT firm. Still I get regular nightmares that I haven't done enough for my parents, so I think of going for UPSC/state PSC exams, but that one year memories haunt me before I even think of preparing for any exam.

P.S 2. I don't blame my friend anymore, as I am much more mature now and understood that it was all my fault.

EDIT 1: Since all those things from the past still continue to eat up my brain, I'm not happy in my current job eitherüòû‚Ä¶

EDIT 2: Thankyou for all your advice‚Ä¶But I keep on stressing myself that I have to compensate for the losses I had due to my stupidity, by doing something so big now that gives me some relief, peace and satisfaction, and will eventually make my parents the happiest..
post.author: sam

post.content:
I‚Äôll give you an interesting fact,

Spoiler alert:- Not what it looks like and scroll to the end for another one.

The crown of ‚ÄúThe fastest production spec vehicle‚Äù is now officially held by a Koenigsegg (Agera RS/US - Spec One:1) with a top speed of 285.44/459.7Kmph (RaceLogic verified) on a closed stretch of highway in Nevada
post.author: sam

post.content:
What are the 5 lessons you learnt living alone?

1.Loneliness - You learn can be alone and not feel lonely or you can be surrounded by people and be completely lonely. The decision lies within you.

2.Freedom - You are free to be your complete self. No external judgements or opinions on how you live your life.

3.Taking Things For Granted - Missed events, birthdays and celebrations. Living alone means making sacrifices. Make them count.

4. Responsibility - Paying bills, cleaning, cooking, doing the dishes, shopping and all other chores soon teach you self-reliance and responsibility. Noone else is coming to do these things for you.

5.Time Management - Losing focus or struggling with productivity becomes a thing of the past. You are the only one who can account for the time you spend. You quickly learn discipline.

6.Enjoying Your Own Company - You will become comfortable with being alone. Suddenly, doing the things you‚Äôve always wanted to do becomes possible and is fun.

7.Relationships - The only person you have to turn to is yourself. The relationships you maintain are the ones that truly matter.

8. Self Confidence - Nothing tests you like living alone. Completing small accomplishments by yourself everyday makes you realize your worth.

9. Finance - Managing money teaches you many lessons. Gone are the days of spending recklessly on things you don‚Äôt value.

10. Independence - You don‚Äôt know independence until you live alone. Adulting becomes a reality. You learn to take care of yourself no matter what.
